title: Kenya: End This Stalemate So That Exams Can Go On
text:
Zimbabwe: Legal Aid Societies Threaten Trade Unions editorial 
The teachers' unions have raised the stakes in the ongoing pay deadlock with the directive to their members to boycott the administration, supervision, and marking of national examinations that are due next month. 
Both the Kenya National Union of Teachers (Knut) and the Kenya Union of Post-Primary Teachers (Kuppet) argue that when they called out their members, they were to boycott any assignment related to teaching and hence cannot participate in the management of the exams. 
Ordinarily, the teachers invigilate, supervise, and mark exams at all levels. At the secondary school level, they organise and make the preparations for practicals. 
If the teachers boycott this process, then the exams will be a sham. 
ENGENDERING CHAOS 
The alternative would be to postpone the exams altogether, which would be traumatising to the candidates. 
Staying without being taught for a month is torturous enough, but having the exams without teachers is tragic. It would create chaos, discredit our exam system, and make our graduates pariahs at the international level. 
Although the Kenya National Examinations Council argues that it has put in place measures to ensure the smooth administration and marking of the exams, it is not convincing that all is well. 
SOLVING THE ISSUE 
The looming tragedy must be avoided. For this reason, we support the initiative by the Catholic bishops to mediate between the unions, the Teachers Service Commission (TSC), and the National Treasury to end the crisis. 
Other religious leaders and respected retired political and industry leaders should join in the initiative to bring the warring parties to the negotiation table. 
The future of thousands of children who have been preparing for years for Standard Eight and Form Four exams is at risk and we urge the protagonists to sober up and resolve the dispute quickly. Kenya
